opener.salute: Друг мой сердечный Князь Григорий Александрович.

body.p: Письмы твои от 5 июля из Ольвиополя я получила вчерась. Любопытна я знать, какие вести получишь от известной особы, чрез посланного от тебя к нему в Польшу.It seems that during Potemkin's visit to St. Petersburg from 4 February until 6 May 1789, he and Catherine agreed that she would write an ostensible letter to Potemkin, in French, which he would then show to Stanislaw Szczesny Feliks Potocki. This was the first step in Catherine and Potemkin's multi-year campaign to make use of Potocki's interest in appealing to Russia for help in reestablishing aristocratic power in Poland. They were so successful that Potocki later became a leader of the Targowica Confederation, which opened the way for the second partition of Poland. As regards Catherine's letter to Potocki, in a missive that can be dated to 10 May 1789, Potemkin reminded Catherine: 'Вы, матушка Государыня, не написали ко мне письма французского, которое б я мог показать Артиллерии Генералу Г[рафу] Потоцкому. Мне оно нужно будет--ему показать, колико Вы на истинный его патриотизм внимаете. Не худо будет, если тут включите поклониться его жене' ('You, Majesty little mother, did not write me a French letter that I could show artillery general Count Potocki. I will need it to show him how much regard you have for his true patriotism. It also would not be bad if you included greetings for his wife'). Catherine sent him the letter with her reply of 13 May. (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin. Lichnaia perepiska 1769-1791, pp. 347-48, Letters 952 and 954.) Catherine followed Potemkin's advice closely: in her letter she 'asked' Potemkin to assure artillery general Count Potocki 'de tout [sic] l'estime que m'a inspirée sa conduite vraiment patriotique' ('of all my esteem for his truly patriotic conduct') and mentioned his wife, 'que vous saluerez aussi de ma part' ('to whom you will also give my greetings') (SIRIO, xlii, pp. 11-12). One of Potemkin's letters of 5 July indicated that the letter had worked: Potemkin had delayed writing to Catherine, 'дожидаясь моего посланного по требованию той особы в Польше, о которооой мне изволили в письме писать' ('awaiting the messenger I had sent on the request of the individual in Poland, about whom you were pleased to write to me in a letter'). Potocki had asked that Potemkin send a reliable messenger to receive important news about the Polish party opposing Russia. On 9 July, Potemkin sent a note conveying Potocki's verbal message: Potocki claimed that royal troops had been deployed along the Dniestr to prevent a Russian retreat (Potemkin denied that the Poles were beating Russian forces there) and that Ignacy Potocki, marshal of Lithuania, was the ringleader of the opposing party. (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin. Lichnaia perepiska 1769-1791, pp. 357, 359, Letters 970 and 974.) Касательно Короля Прусского, кажется, все возможное делается, чтоб его удержать и гнев его умяхчить.This was a reply to the next point in Potemkin's letter, following the mention of the messenger to Potocki: 'Нужно мне, кормилица, остеречься. И, как ни есть, ласково Короля Прусского удержать в его стремлении' ('I need to be careful, nurse [a term of endearment frequently used by Potemkin for Catherine]. And somehow gently restrain the King of Prussia in his efforts') (Ekaterina II i G.A. Potemkin. Lichnaia perepiska 1769-1791, p. 357, Letter 970). On the Prussian libels attacking Potemkin, see Catherine's letter of 6 July. Как выведешь магазейны из Польши, то ему уже надлежит выдумывать новые лжи и клеветы, чтоб поджигать поляков.
Теперь шведы до Аньялы прогнаны, осталось их выжить из Кюменогородского поста.

На второе письмо твое, полученное чрез Н[иколая] И[вановича] Салт[ыкова], я тебе скажу, что я все твои слова и что ты мне говорил зимой и весною приводила на память, но, признаюсь, что тут есть много несообразного. Рибопьер о всем знал, он и брат его жены сосватали. Говорил ли он тебе или нет о сем чистосердечно, не ведаю, но помню, что ты мне единожды говорил, что Рибо[пьер] тебе сказал, что друг его достоин быть выгнан от меня, чему я дивилась. Естьли б зимою тебе открылись, для чего ты мне не сказал тогда? Много бы огорчения излишнего тем прекратилось и давно уже он женат был.

Я ничей тиран никогда не была и принуждения ненавидую, est il possible que Vous m’ayés méconnue jusqu’à ce point et que dans Votre esprit la générosité de mon caractère Vous ait échappée et que Vous m’ayés cru un vilain égoiste, Vous m’auriés guérie tout d’un coup en me disant la vérité.

Правду говоришь, когда пишешь, что ты у меня в милости ни по каким обстоятельствам, кои вреда тебе причинить не могут. Прошу сохранить ко мне сию доверенность; она мне драгоценна и я ее заслуживаю. Злодеи твои, конечно, у меня успеха иметь не могут, mais, mon Ami, ne soyés pas aussi ombrageux sans aucune raison et mettés-Vous au dessus des ombrages minutieux. От досад, конечно, колико только можно, тебя избавлю. Утешь ты меня, приласкай нас.

NB У нас сердце доброе и нрав весьма приятный, без злобы и коварства et un désir très déterminé de bien faire. Четыре правила имеем, кои сохранить старание будет, а именно: быть верен, скромен, привязан и благодарен до крайности, avec cela ce Noiraud a de fort beaux yeux et ne manque pas de lecture, en un mot il me plaît et aucune sorte d’ennui jusqu’ici ne s’est glissé entre nous; au contraire voilà la quatrième semaine qui se passe très agréablement.

Я приказала Гр[афу] Безбор[одко] выжить Фельдм[аршала] Румянц[ева] из Ясс: оне лутче знают как, нежели я. Это второй том его житья в Данцихе.In 1762, Peter III had placed Rumyantsev in charge of his mission to reclaim Holstein from Denmark. Relieved of his command at Catherine's accession to the throne, Rumyantsev lived in Danzig with his mistress, despite Catherine's generous permission to take the waters or to live on his estates, and, in January 1763, her attempt to recruit him back into the service. Only in November-December 1764 did he accept an appointment as governor-general in Ukraine. See his biography page.

closer.signed: Прощай, мой друг. Извини, буде я тебе сим письмом и чтением его причинила скуку.

opener.salute: My dear friend Prince Grigory Aleksandrovich.

body.p: I received yesterday your letters of 5 July from Olviopol. I am curious to know what news you will receive from the certain individual, via the messenger you sent to him in Poland. As regards the King of Prussia, it seems that everything possible is being done to restrain him and to soften his anger. Once you get the stores out of Poland, he will have to think up new lies and slanders to enflame the Poles.
Now the Swedes have been chased back to Anjala; it remains to oust them from the post at Kyumenogorod.

In reply to your second letter, received via N[ikolai] I[vanovich] Salt[ykov], I will tell you that I recalled all your words and what you said to me in winter and spring. But I must admit that there is a lot here that is incomprehensible. Ribaupierre knew about everything: he and his wife's brother were the go-betweens. I do not know if he spoke to you candidly about it or not, but I remember you once saying to me that Ribaupierre told you his friend deserved to be dismissed, which surprised me. If they confided in you over the winter, why did you not tell me then? It would have put an end to much unnecessary affliction, and he would have been married long ago.

I am no one's tyrant, and I detest compulsion. Can you possibly have known me so poorly? Could the generosity of my character have escaped you in your judgment? Could you have thought me a mean egotist? You would have cured me instantly by telling me the truth.

You are telling the truth when you write that my favour toward you does not depend on any circumstances that could harm you. I ask you to maintain this confidence in me: I value it and deserve it. Your enemies cannot succeed with me, of course. But, my Friend, do not be so easily offended for no reason and rise above minute offenses. I will, of course, spare you annoyances as much as possible. Comfort me, show us affection.

NB We have a good heart and a most pleasant temper, without malice or guile and a very determined desire to do well. We have four rules, which effort will be made to uphold: to be loyal, modest, affectionate, and grateful in the extreme. Furthermore this Brunet has very beautiful eyes and is not unread. In a word, I like him, and up to now no troubles of any kind have come between us. On the contrary, this is the fourth week that has been spent most agreeably.
I have ordered Co[unt] Bezbor[odko] to oust Field-M[arshal] Rumyants[ev] from Iași. He knows better than I how to do it. This is the second volume of his sojourn in Danzig.

closer.signed: Farewell, my friend. Forgive me if I have bored you with this letter and the reading of it.
